Award.AwardTitle: Finite-dimensional Hopf algebras and their representations
Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal will study the structure and representations of certain Hopf algebras, especially those Hopf algebras constructed from finite groups. A major topic concerns the Frobenius-Schur indicators of the representations. These indicators are invariants of the tensor category of representations of the Hopf algebra, and can be extended to more general objects. They should give information not only on the representations of a Hopf algebra, but they also serve as a tool in proving more general facts about Hopf algebras themselves. The methods for many of the problems involve the theory of finite groups.

Hopf algebras are special algebraic objects which arose in topology and algebraic groups in the 1940's and 1950's. However since then they have appeared in other parts of mathematics, such as geometry (knot theory), and in several parts of mathematical physics (conformal field theory and statistical mechanics). In many cases Hopf algebras can be used to give invariants of these structures which help to understand and classify them. Thus they are of general interest.

POR.DRECONTENT:
I made progress on the topics in the proposal, concerning numerical invariants called ``indicators'' for representations of Hopf algebras. These numbers are connected to problems in mathematical physics, to conformal field theory in particular. 

Progress was made on three research papers. The first, joint with M. Vega and S. Witherspoon, concerned twisted versions of the indicators mentioned above and their relation to the usual indicators. This paper has appeared in print. 

The second, joint with A. Castano, S, Natale, M. Vega, and C. Walton, has been accepted for publication in another  journal. This paper was not explicitly on indicators, but rather on some more fundamental questions on structure of finite-dimensional Hopf algebras which could be applied in the future to representations.

The third paper is in preparation. 

I presented my work at meetings here at USC, and also in Canada, China, and Japan. I was a co-organizer of the meeting in China (at the Chern Institute), at the national American Math Society meeting in Atlanta, and at a meeting at UC San Diego, concerning ``tensor categories''. One exampleof such categoreis are the representations of a Hopf algebra.  

One graduate student was supported in Spring 2017. I also had four collaborators visit, one from the US, one from Canada and two from Germany.
